title: John Laws Farewelled, Rage Baiting, US House Votes Unanimously To Release Epstein Files | 10 News+
description: Roblox, known as one of the world’s largest gaming platforms, will now request users verify their age. The move comes after a negotiation with eSafety Commissioner Julia Inman Grant, who confirmed Roblox was threatened with fines if they failed to comply. Grant expressed she had concerns, prior to the agreement, that Roblox was becoming a “playground for paedophiles.”   Today was the final sign off for talkback titan John Laws, who has been farewelled at a state funeral in Sydney’s CBD. Russell Crowe, Barnaby Joyce, Marcia Hines and Dawn Fraser were all among the attendees who came together to remember “the golden tonsils.”  It’s been 80 years since Thomas the Tank Engine chugged onto our screens, and the locomotive is still changing lives today. 15-year-old superfan Cody has been obsessed with Thomas & Friends from toddlerhood. Thomas & Friends became the bridge that helped therapists connect with him and break through barriers in communication and play.   Experts are warning that social media is keeping us angry and online, trapping us in a vicious cycle. 10 News+ spoke to Annie Knight, the OnlyFans star behind multiple controversial sex stunts, about how 'rage baiting' can be one of the most effective tools for a content creator. title: Tropical Cyclone Fina Triggers Flood Warning For Australia’s North | 10 News
description: The tropical low off Australia's coast has intensified into a cyclone, and it has officially been named Fina. A flood watch has been issued for part of the country's north as authorities prepare for the system to make landfall. title: UK Spy Agency MI5 Issues Warning To British Politicians Over Chinese Spies | 10 News
description: The UK's spy agency MI5 has issued a stark warning to British politicians. Chinese agents are posing as recruiters to target people who work in Parliament in a bid to steal sensitive documents and gain a strategic advantage. The alert says China's spy agency is using headhunters to conduct outreach at scale, including through websites such as LinkedIn. title: Man Steals Car With Baby Inside | 10 News
description: Police are searching for a man who stole a vehicle before realising there was a baby in the backseat.  A sleeping child was inside a car in a supermarket carpark in Shepparton, Victoria while the victim quickly ran into the store at about 2pm on November 14.  An unknown male then stole the red Volkswagen and reversed it out of the carpark, before realising there was a baby in the backseat.  The man then took the baby out of the car and placed it in a nearby box, the child was located immediately after the victim returned.  The stolen car was located on November 15 in the Mooroopna area, with police releasing CCTV of the incident in the hope the public will be able to assist them in their investigation.  Police describe the man as being aged in his 20s to 30s, a slim build, 165cm tall, wearing a black cap backwards, navy headphones, a blue Golden State basketball singlet, black shorts, light blue runners and black sweatbands on both wrists. title: Indonesia’s Mount Semeru Eruption Prompts Travel Warning & Evacuations | 10 News
description: Indonesia’s Mount Semeru, the tallest peak on Java Island, has erupted, prompting evacuations and leading authorities to raise the alert to the highest level.  Ash clouds as high as 2 kilometres high were seen spewing above the mountain's peak and a mixture of rock, lava and gas travelled up to 7km down its slopes several times from midday to dusk.  More than 300 residents in the three villages most at risk in the district of Lumajang were evacuated to government shelters, but no casualties have been reported.  The Australian Bureau of Meteorology's Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre has issued a red aviation alert following the eruption. title: 267 People Rescued After South Korean Ferry Runs Aground | 10 News
description: All 267 people aboard a South Korean passenger ferry have been rescued after it ran aground on rocks off the country's south-east coast.  Authorities said the Queen Jenuvia 2 was travelling from Jeju Island to Mokpo before it became stuck on a reef and unable to move, but there is currently no risk of it sinking or capsizing.  It’s understood 27 people suffered minor injuries and there have been no casualties.
